item.title: Best in What Way, For Who, When?
item.description: Every Choice is a Tradeoff Everything is a tradeoff, always. The longer I live the more evident this is true. I used to be and still sometimes struggle with being a perfectionist, I like to weigh all the options, see every possibility before committing to a decision, sometimes even going back over it again and rethinking the decision, this has never served me well. “A good plan, violently executed now, is better than a perfect plan next week” — George Patton

item.title: Big Picture Thinking
item.description: One of the most productive things I’ve managed to do has been to cut things out of my life because they weren’t the most important. Focus is as much what you don’t do as what you do. So it becomes even more important to recognize and prioritize the things that actually matter, especially if these are along the important and impactful but not urgent spectrum. So then I have to ask myself, what are the things that actually matter?

item.title: Awe, Wonder & Pleasant Surprises
item.description: Cultivating curiosity and wonder are what allow me to be productive, to get things done and to keep procrastination at bay, I find that they are also core emotions to my functioning well as a person and key my own happiness or contentment. I believe that the distillation of it is feedback and enjoying that feedback. Look at a baby splashing water, they are surprised by how their actions caused a reaction, they are surprised and often delighted by that direct feedback.

item.title: A Theory Of Happiness
item.description: A Definition What Makes People Happy? Mastery - Being good at what you do, competence Belonging - Social relationships Autonomy - Freedom to make decisions Needs satisfied Happiness is independent of outcomes but we allow our feelings about outcomes to direct it

item.title: King of Dragon Pass - Game Mechanics Study
item.description: Released in 1999, this is one of those games that some people say nothing like it has come out since. Turn based strategy and role playing game. it’s like a primitive city builder, kinda. backstory choices to create a culture for your team appointing leaders and advisors the hints they give based on how skilled they are Personal Thoughts: I expected more combat and less city planning choices. The focus on the gods and the mythology is interesting, I should incorporate something like that into my game.
